fields.description:
*Summary*

Consider turning Workspace ONE as one of the supported IdP for SAML integration.

Current list of supported IdP's for SAML integration with Atlassian Cloud.

||Identity provider||Set up instructions||
|Azure|See: [The Azure help page|https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/active-directory-saas-atlassian-cloud-tutorial] or [Atlassian Cloud app|https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/marketplace/partners/atlassian/atlassiancloud] 
We don't officially support ADFS, so we recommend using Azure Active Directory instead.|
|Bitium|[Configuring SAML for Atlassian Cloud|https://support.bitium.com/administration/saml-atlassian]|
|Centrify|[Centrify's help page|https://docs.centrify.com/en/centrify/appref/?_ga=2.143391413.1277756220.1508797934-1918052083.1508349314#page/cloudhelp%2Fg-n%2Fsaas_appref_JIRA_Cloud_specifications.html%23ww1221337]|
|Okta|[How to Configure SAML 2.0 for Atlassian Cloud|http://mandrillapp.com/track/click/11828703/saml-doc.okta.com?]|
|OneLogin|See: [the OneLogin help page|https://support.onelogin.com/hc/en-us/articles/217040946] [the OneLogin app|https://admin.us.onelogin.com/apps/new/80915] 
You'll need to be logged in to OneLogin to see those pages.|
|Ping|Not currently supported, but instructions to come soon.|

*Suggestion*

Provide official documentation to integrate SAML using Workspace ONE.
fields.summary: Consider supporting Workspace ONE as IdP for SAML integration

fields.description:
Currently, this document outlined that: 

https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/domain-verification-873871234.html#Domainverification-Verifyadomain

_You can verify more than one domain – just add extra domains using the *Add domain* button, and click *Verify* for each domain you want to verify._ 

But you will only have a "Verify Domain" button when you wanted to add an extra domain. There is no "Add domain" button.
fields.summary: Update documentation on adding extra domain

fields.description:
h3. Summary

Some system administrators, may request we lock log in for a particular instance to certain domains, after SAML is integrated, this would straight up the security allowing only personnel from trusted domains to log in to a cloud instance.

h3. Suggestion

Have the ability to restrict access to only verified domains after SAML gets integrated.

h3. Note

Currently, after an integration with SAML all login requests belonging to the integrated domain would be redirected to the SSO portal, however, if there are existing accounts outside the claimed domain they would go through the regular flow logging through id.atlassian.com.
fields.summary: Restrict the access to certain domains after SAML integration

fields.description:
{panel:title=Release update}
Hi All,

We are excited to announce that we have shipped the Authentication policies feature. Using this feature you can test SSO on a few accounts before enabling it across your organization ([https://www.atlassian.com/software/access/guide/elements/authentication-policies#why-apply-multiple-authentication-policies]). We are still in the last leg of the rollout. If your organization doesn’t have the feature yet, file a support ticket ([https://support.atlassian.com/contact/#/]) and we will enable the feature for you.

Thanks,

The Atlassian Access team.
{panel}
Enabling SSO can be an iterative process and there are no proof of concept options.

The implications of enabling SAML can have wide spread negative consequences if not configured correctly and is complicated further if the Org Admin doesn't have a backup account to let them back to delete the SAML configuration or make SSO changes.
h3. Suggested Solution

Allow Org Admins the ability to either simulate or test SSO settings without committing to make the cutover. In doing so, it would boost confidence and admins can better plan for the actual implementation/cutover. Also, allow Org Admins to test Atlassian Access REST API.
h3. Workaround (Optional) 

Advise Org Admins to carefully review documentation and consider attempting to cutover to SSO during non peak hours which can include pre-communications to the user community and a follow up note to indicate go or no-go.
fields.summary: Allow Org Admins the ability to test SSO

fields.description:
h3. Summary
This bug ticket shares similar symptom as IM-91, but it has a different factor affecting it.
When using a password policy, it is possible to set the required password strength to one of various possible strengths. The strength of the password reported by the password change page before submitting does not show the conclusion that will be reported by the Validator.

This means that it is possible to require a "Strong" password, Show the password you are trying to use as "Very Strong", and get an error that "your password must be at least 'Strong'"

h3. Environment
Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
- Set your Organization to require a "Strong" password.
- Using an 8-character password, ensure the password barely makes it to "Very Strong" in the interface.
- Submit this as your new password.

h3. Expected Results
Either the password is shown to be the same strength as the validator, or the password is accepted as "Very Strong".

h3. Actual Results
The Password is rejected as not sufficiently Strong.
   !Password-Error.png|thumbnail! 
h3. Notes
N/A

h3.Workaround
The only workaround is to use a stronger password with more characters.
fields.summary: password change page reports strength of password as stronger than the validator does

fields.description:
*Summary*

According [to this documentation|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/saml-single-sign-on-943953302.html#SAMLsinglesign-on-Supportedidentityproviders] Atlassian only officially support the following IdP's to integrate Atlassian Cloud apps with SAML:

{quote}
Azure
Okta
Onelogin
Bitium
Centrify
{quote}

*Suggestion*

As more enterprise customers join our Cloud offering, it would be nice for those who use SAP as their ERP to have support to integrate SAP SSO solution (SAP Identity Management) with Atlassian apps.
fields.summary: Consider officially supporting SAP IDM as IdP

fields.description:
{panel:title=Update on external user security}
We are actively working on providing customers with a solution to enforce 2FA on non-managed users. This is something that is [committed to on our public roadmap|https://www.atlassian.com/roadmap/cloud?&search=external%20user%20security].
{panel}
We are a bit surprised that two-step verification is only allowed for managed domains.

As many company we are working with subcontractors that have their own domain that we can't manage.

As we need secure connexion on our instance for every user, it would be a great security improvement to be able to enforce two-step verification for every user.

In the meantime, it's makes us unable to be compliant with our security commitments.

 

Thanks for the attention you'll pay for this issue.

Romain
fields.summary: Enforce security policies for users not on verified domains

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

As reflected in [ID-6343|https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/ID-6343] , enabling SAML in a Cloud environment can impact existing accounts of the same domain that already exist in another Cloud environment. 

For example, SAML can force all accounts under acme.com to redirect to an Identity Provider (Azure, Okta, etc). In other words, any acme.com account would be subject to SSO redirection no matter the Cloud URL they attempt to access. 


h3. Suggested Solution

In the *Before you begin* section of our [SAML documentation |https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/saml-single-sign-on-943953302.html] _and_ the *What you need to know* section in the the *SAML single sign-on* configuration, suggesting to add this as the first bullet point: "Before enabling SAML, contact support to assess your cutover plans to help ensure the process goes as expected"

h3. Workaround (Optional) 

Reach out to support and request assistance if you are unsure whether enabling SAML will introduce problems and potentially impact the login experience in a negative way.
fields.summary: SAML > Before you begin ; check for multiple Cloud environments

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Currently, users can issue API tokens on id.atlassian.com even belonging to an organization.
h3. Suggested Solution

If a user belongs to an organization, let the admin choose these options:
 * Prohibit users from issuing API tokens
 * Make the creation of API tokens admin-only
 * Let the admin browse the history of API token creation

h3. Workaround

None
fields.summary: Ability to control issuing API tokens for organization admin

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

Re: https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/domain-verification-873871234.html

When following the steps to verify a domain using DNS, its not clear how the Org Admin should proceed if they discover an existing TXT record containing an Atlassian token


h3. Suggested Solution

Require the person that uploaded the TXT use their email address as the name of said TXT record along with the Cloud URL in which it was intended. 

h3. Workaround (Optional) 

Org Admins will need to check with colleagues to determine who uploaded the TXT record and for what purpose
fields.summary: Domain Verification > Existing TXT record with Atlassian token

fields.description:
We should update our troubleshooting section here:

https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/secure-your-account-with-two-step-verification-939505063.html#Secureyouraccountwithtwo-stepverification-trouble

Suggesting we add a bullet point that warns the person attempting to enable 2FA that they may be a *Managed Account* rather than Unmanaged Account
fields.summary: Troubleshooting 2FA > User attempting to enable 2FA is a Managed Account

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Azure may be sending users to the Atlassian login page without completing the SAML handshake.

h3. Impact
The users have to input their email address on the Atlassian login page, then be authenticated with their SSO.
fields.summary: Azure is not automatically authenticating through SSO after the SAML update

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When using a password policy, it is possible to set the required password strength to one of various possible strengths. The strength of the password reported by the password change page before submitting does not show the conclusion that will be reported by the Validator.

This means that it is possible to require a "Strong" password, Show the password you are trying to use as "Very Strong", and get an error that "your password must be at least 'Strong'"

h3. Environment
Cloud

h3. Steps to Reproduce
- Set your Organization to require a "Strong" password.
- Using an 8-character password, ensure the password barely makes it to "Very Strong" in the interface.
- Submit this as your new password.

h3. Expected Results
Either the password is shown to be the same strength as the validator, or the password is accepted as "Very Strong".

h3. Actual Results
The Password is rejected as not sufficiently Strong.
  !Password-Error.png|thumbnail! 
h3. Notes
N/A

h3.Workaround
The only workaround is to use a stronger password with more characters.
fields.summary: password change page reports strength of password as stronger than the validator does

fields.description:
This error happens right after the user logs in to the IdP Auth0 with 

"Oops, there was an error logging you in." with no errors in the server logs.

There are not many details in the SAML requests and the Auth0 logs show that the auth was successful. The login is redirected to the following URL:

https://id.atlassian.com/login/callback?continue=https://HOST.atlassian.net/login?redirectCount=1&error=access_denied&error_description=Cannot use 'in' operator to search for 'requiresPasswordChange' in [object Object]&state=XXXXXX
fields.summary: SAML users logging through Auth0 as an IdP have the string "[object Object]" as their user_metadata and app_metadata
REST API to determine if a password represents an API token

fields.description:
{panel:title=Release Update}
Hi,

We are excited to announce that we have shipped the Authentication policies feature. Using this feature you can test out security policies on individual managed accounts before enabling it across your organization ([https://www.atlassian.com/software/access/guide/elements/authentication-policies#why-apply-multiple-authentication-policies]). We are still in the last leg of the rollout. If your organization doesn’t have the feature yet, file a support ticket ([https://support.atlassian.com/contact/#/]) and we will enable the feature for you.

Thanks,

The Atlassian Access team.
{panel}
 

Problem Definition

As an Org Admin, before applying security policies to managed accounts its important to first demonstrate the features on an individual account before enforcing to all managed accounts.

Suggested Solution

Allow Org Admins the ability the enable two factor authentication and password policies on an individual basis

Why this is important

As an Org Admin, its important we test security policies to effectively support the managed accounts

1. The Org Admin would test the waters and ensure the process works as expected
 2. The Org Admin may decide to document the process for internal purposes and thus enabling the features beforehand to effectively support and field questions from managed account holders if needed

+ Service accounts: The user should have the option to exclude single users from password polices, for example, a service account cannot have the password changed according to the password polices.

Workaround

Only unmanaged accounts can be enabled on an individual basis
fields.summary: Ability to Apply Security Policies for Individual Managed Accounts

fields.description:
{panel:title=Release update}
Hi,

We are excited to announce that we have shipped the Authentication policies feature. Using this feature you can bypass SSO for certain managed accounts. ([https://www.atlassian.com/software/access/guide/elements/authentication-policies#why-apply-multiple-authentication-policies]). We are still in the last leg of the rollout. If your organization doesn’t have the feature yet, file a support ticket ([https://support.atlassian.com/contact/#/]) and we will enable the feature for you.

Thanks,

The Atlassian Access team.
{panel}
h3.  Problem Definition

For unmanaged accounts that are leveraged for purposes similar to add-on accounts, admins have no way of enforcing security policies.

In contrast, for managed accounts, admins have no method to bypass SSO initiated logins.
h3. Suggested Solution

Allow Org Admins the ability the option to configure a managed account to use conventional SSO settings or force authentication against id.atlassian.com *but* still enforce security policies.
h3. Why this is important

As a Site-admin, its not feasible to establish and maintain local service accounts for a few reasons:

1. Users that login to other Cloud instances wouldn't be redirected to SSO but they would still have security policies applied 
 2. Atlassian Accounts creates more administrative overhead (now that we have managed accounts it can be viewed as being uncomplimentary)
 3. Atlassian Accounts cannot be enforced with security policies
h3. Workaround

No workaround.
fields.summary: Allow bypassing SSO Authentication for Managed Accounts

fields.description:
h4. Summary
The update my configuration banner style for the SAML confiuration page is broken on all latest version browsers and covering the data that needs to be replaced on the Identity Provider.

h4. Error
 !Screen Shot 2018-02-05 at 12.42.44.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Workaround
# You can click on the field then press *Ctrl + A* to select all the text then copy it to retrieve the information.
# Or you can inspect element (Chrome) on the banner yellow area then erase the style property of the HTML tag:
#*  !image-2018-02-05-12-48-37-411.png|thumbnail! 
#*  !image-2018-02-05-12-49-05-159.png|thumbnail! 
#*  !image-2018-02-05-12-49-31-215.png|thumbnail! 
#*  !image-2018-02-05-12-49-52-033.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: SAML update my configuration banner is covering the SP details.

fields.description: design net banking integrate
fields.summary: design net banking integrate

fields.description:
{panel:title= Implementation of New Features Policy|titleBGColor=#e0efff}
(i)
At the moment, we can't set an ETA for this feature to be released, since there's a number of factors that determine how our product team prioritizes new features.
 You can learn more by reading [Implementation of New Features Policy|https://confluence.atlassian.com/support/implementation-of-new-features-policy-201294576.html].
{panel}
h4. Summary

If you create an organization, you only have the option to remove verified domains and linked sites functionality, but do not have the option to remove the created organization. You are able to rename the organization, but not remove it completely.
h4. Suggestion

Allow organization administrators to delete organization as this can make the functionality confusing.
h3. Note

You can cancel the subscription from *Billing*. Refer to the document [Unsubscribe from Atlassian Access|https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/unsubscribe-from-atlassian-access-948237308.html] for more details.

It is also possible to [transfer an organization|https://support.atlassian.com/organization-administration/docs/transfer-products-to-another-organization/] into another organization, and thereby "delete" the original organization.
fields.summary: Allow organization administrators to delete organizations

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When clicking on the verify domain button in Microsoft Edge nothing happens.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create an organization
# Access it using Microsoft Edge
# Try to verify a domain on the domain section

h3. Expected Results

The domain should be added to the domain list.

h3. Actual Results

Nothing happens and nothing is logged on the browser console.
 [^domain_edge.mp4] 

h3.Workaround

Use another browser.
fields.summary: Unable to verify domains in Microsoft Edge or IE

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

As an Org Admin, its important to determine the cloud instance(s) in which a user has access 



h3. Suggested Solution

Add a column in managed accounts with the Cloud instance. 

If the field is not populated with a Cloud URL, that is an indication that the user hasn't verified their email which is helpful from a troubleshooting standpoint when users can't login.
fields.summary: Associate Managed account with a Cloud Instance

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When a domain is claimed, we send an email out to the Organization Admin:

{quote}
Hi <End User>,

We're writing to let you know that your Atlassian account is now being managed by your Atlassian Cloud administrator. 

This won't change the way you log in to Atlassian products or how you use them. 
However, from now on if you want to update your email address, you'll need to contact your Atlassian Cloud administrator. 
{quote}

Important details are omitted such as:
 
1. The atlassian cloud administrator
2. The atlassian cloud url 
3. For IDP initiated SAML, the SSO admin (as it would directly impact the way users login)

h3. Suggested Solution

Include more details in the notifications so there is less ambiguity in terms of why the information is necessary for the receiver
fields.summary: Improve notification email to end users when domain is verified and accounts become managed
Warn Organization Admin that emails will be sent to users after claiming a domain

fields.description:
Problem Definition
Similar to IM-33, when SAML is enabled, groups have to be created both in the identity provider and Atlassian Cloud.

As an admin, I have several groups in Azure (group1, group2,etc). I want to have these groups in Atlassian Cloud in User Management. 

Suggested Solution
Allow groups to be automatically created and updated in Atlassian Cloud when the group is established.
fields.summary: Enable group sync when SAML enabled

fields.description:
MFA is an excellent feature and helps with regulatory compliance requirements (DFS) for some states. One feature that would be worth investigating is a 30-day MFA verified option. This would essentially allow users to verify via MFA soft token and remain verified for 30-days when a box is checked at the soft token prompt page. Checking the box before logging in will allow users to remained verified for 30-days before being prompted again for a MFA soft token verification and again the option to remain verified for 30-days.

The configuration setting on whether or not this check box appears is a toggle for the admin to enable/disable. Otherwise, the Identity Manager default configuration requires a MFA soft token to login without the option to remain verified for 30-days.
fields.summary: MFA 30-day Re-validation

fields.description:
https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/organization-administration-938859734.html

For the Org page, suggesting we add a quick paragraph to explain that renaming an Organization is accomplished in the Details page and that changing the name has no impact on users or existing policies.
fields.summary: Document Renaming an Organization

fields.description:
h4. Summary
The "Edit account* functionality is not capable of loading user profiles that have a mismatch on the email domain for the letter case.

h4. How to reproduce
# Have an organization with a domain verified. (ie: example.com)
# Have an user that the email was created with uppercase letters on the domain. (ie: user@Example.com)
# Go to your organization's managed accounts and click to *Edit account*.

h5. Expected behaviour
The edit account page loads with the profile.

h5. Actual result
An error is displayed.
 !actual_result_ss.png|thumbnail! 

h4. Notes
The issue is only reproduced for already existing accounts, we've modified the user creation process to always put the emails in lowercase, which avoids this problem for future accounts.

h4. Workaround
There is no workaround, please contact the [Atlassian support|https://support.atlassian.com] for assistance, mentioning this bug.
fields.summary: The "Edit account" functionality is not capable of loading user profiles that have a mismatch on the email domain for the letter case.

fields.description:
h4. Summary

It is currently not possible to check with Identity Manager which are the instances that have users from a verified domain.

h4. Suggestion

Add an option to see the instances that have users from a verified domain.

h4. Why this is important

I would be important to e.g. be able to provide proper communications about SAML implementation.
fields.summary: Ability to check which instances have users from a verified domain

fields.description:
Page containing incorrect instructions:

[https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/saml-single-sign-on-939718272.html]

See section entitled: What should I do if I'm having issues after updating my SAML single sign-on configuration?

The second step states:
{quote}Go to the SAML single sign-on settings page of your Atlassian Cloud site, and click the Restore my original configuration button (you need to click the 'info' icon to see the button).
{quote}
The Restore my original configuration button does not exist.  It isn't clear if the instructions are only valid after Feb. 9th or if the button should be there now.

The current workaround is to delete your SAML configuration, but this generates new URL which will need to replace any existing setting with your SAML provider when you are ready to try again.
fields.summary: Incorrect instructions for disabling SAML

fields.description:
h4. Suggestion

Provide the ability to download SP SAML metadata in XML and/or publish it on an URL to be consumed.
fields.summary: Provide the ability to download SP SAML metadata and/or display it on an URL to be consumed.

fields.description:
At the moment the only way to recover access for the Administrator account is to have a non-domain account email setup. With Identity Manager this same feature exists. What I'm proposing is that the feature be added to allow for a master account be configured that exists outside of SSO. This master account could/should require MFA to still log in, but this would allow administrators to setup an account that will have access to their instance in the event SSO breaks.

There are plenty of other examples where cloud service providers offer the option of allow a non-SSO account, from the same domain, that uses MFA be setup to manage their instance.
fields.summary: Secondary Access Alternatives
SAML Single Sign On > What You Need to Know

fields.description:
There is dialog box that comes up when you attempt to delete the SAML configuration: 
{quote}
Delete SAML configuration?

Your users will get back to logging in with their credentials.
{quote}
As an admin, I would like to better understand the implications (if any) if I decide to unsubscribe to Identity Manager _before_ deleting the SAML configuration. 

In particular, how exactly would this impact users (both those already logged in and those that will subsequently login at some point in the near future). 

Does "Your users will get back to logging in with their credentials" mean users still login with their email address? Will passwords be impacted? What if a password policy is already established? 

Ideally we could add a paragraph to expand on this topic at the end of the SSO document: 

https://confluence.atlassian.com/cloud/saml-single-sign-on-939718272.html
fields.summary: Implications when deleting a SAML configuration

fields.description:
h4. Summary
Once an admin has configured a SAML setting, it applies to all users on their domains. Instantly. 
This makes it really tricky for an admin to either test their configuration, or run a "sandpit" IdP instance. 

Like many IT tools, big customers will have a "dev" instance of their IdP for testing stuff, and then the "prod" instance of their IdP. Our current SAML setup has no way of incrementally testing a SAML config for a customer. It's all or nothing. 

h4. Suggestions
- Run a test login as part of configuration
- Have a "enable" or "test' flag
fields.summary: Improve an admin's testing capability with SAML

fields.description:
{panel:title=(i) UPDATE 2018-06-13 | borderStyle=| borderColor=| titleBGColor=#e0efff| bgColor=}

We understand the limitations of the Managed Accounts screen within admin.atlassian.com. Our product team is working to add more functionality in the coming weeks and months. In the meantime, we can provide a list of billable users that shows the name, email address, and product/site that the user has access to. We can provide this list in CSV format to any Organization Admin on the account. Note that the request must come from a listed Organization Admin, if you are not an Organization Admin, please have that person [contact us|https://support.atlassian.com/contact/] directly to request this information.

{panel}


h3. Problem Definition

Organization admins aren't able to export a list of Managed Accounts in their Organization

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow Organization Admins to export a list of Managed Accounts to a CSV file

h3. Why this is important

Organization Admins will need to audit their Managed Accounts to avoid paying the extra $3 per user for users they don't need in their organization.
fields.summary: As an organization admin I want to be able to export a list of managed accounts in my organization

fields.description: When editing account details there is no cancel button. It would be nice to cancel out as opposed to closing the tab and doesn't feel as graceful as dismissing with a button.
fields.summary: Edit Account Details > Requesting Cancel Button

fields.description:
h4. Summary
For administrators that support more than one Cloud site and companies, it becomes a blocker when this administrator needs to create a new organization for another company she/he supports as the option is not available, having to create a temporary user to create the organization, grant access to the primary user and then deleting this temporary user.

h4. Suggestion
Allow organization administrators to create new organizations.
fields.summary: Allow organization administrators to create new organizations

fields.description:
The search field says to "search by name" but the only two columns on the screen are *User* and *Email Address*.  Could we update the message "Search by User". 

Ideally we could also search by email address. 

The search criteria does not go away unless manually removed and so when you navigate to another organization, when you go to Managed accounts you'll observe the search criteria from the last search (from another organization).
fields.summary: Managed accounts > Searching behavior

fields.description:
h4. Summary
The documentation is not clear on explaining how organizations will show for organization administrators for multiple organizations, it may get confusing for some administrators to see other organizations and there is no justification on the documentation to shed some light.

h4. Documentation Update
Include multi-organization management information when an org admin is part of multiple organizations.
fields.summary: (Documentation Update) Include multi-organization management information when an org admin is part of multiple organizations.

fields.description:
h4. Summary
As an administrator, I would like to have the process of performing the most immediate actions on the first screen to manage the accounts, this would improve user experience and speed up the process of managing users, when not editing the account details itself.

h4. Suggestion
Add an options menu instead of Edit account on users for the Organization managed accounts screen, giving options like (Edit account, reset password, disable account, disable two-step verification).

h4. Additional notes
This suggestion comes also from the fact that the actions listed under the Options menu are actually immediate on the Edit account menu, not needing to click on Save.
fields.summary: Add an options menu instead of Edit account on users for the Organization managed accounts screen

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition

When a customer has several separate Cloud instances with different URLs on the same domain, they cannot create and link two separate applications within their Identity Provider as the Entity Provider URL is configured at organization level and not at instance level. Each of the separate applications will have a separate Entity Provider URL.

This disrupts the Identity Provider initatiated workflow as it doesn't allow the customer to create separate applications for each of the instances and manage separately the access to those aplications.
h3. Suggested Solution

Have the option to configure SAML separately by instance rather than by Organization or Domain.
h3. Workaround (Optional) 

When users log in via the Cloud instance URL (Service Provider initiated workflow) the users can still access.
fields.summary: Have the option to configure SAML at instance level rather than at organization level

fields.description:
h4. Summary
Create a filter on the Managed accounts screen to show Atlassian accounts not verified, today, when an email is edited, the account needs to be verified again, because of this, it is not listed under the managed accounts, losing visibility of these users.

Plus, if a typo is done on an email change, it will not be possible to change it back, it is expected not to be able to view if the typo was done on the domain and it is not verified, but typos on the email prefix can still be fixed if the user is shown on managed accounts.
fields.summary: Create a filter on the Managed accounts screen to show Atlassian accounts not verified

fields.description:
h4. Suggestion

# The field could validate and not allow white spaces when URLs are pasted there, maybe wiping them out automatically or informing the user, this can prevent misconfigurations as a white space character is enough to break the SAML integration.
# An additional validation could be to check if the URLs provided are not the same for the Service Provider (Atlassian Entity ID and SSO URL) and inform the user, sometimes customers will be confused and add this information instead of the Identity Provider's information, this could prevent other misconfigurations.
fields.summary: Add more validation routines to the SAML fields for Identity Provider Entity ID and SSO URL

fields.description:
h4. Summary

2FA gives a "Transaction not found" when validating the verification code on Safari, the issue is inconsistent, happening mostly when auto filling security applications are used (ie: 1Password), it can be reproduced manually.

h4. Steps to reproduce
# Go to id.atlassian.com
# Get your verification code on clipboard
# Fill up email and press enter
# Fill up the password and press enter
# As soon as the auth.atlassian.com page loads, paste the verification code and *press enter* quickly

h5. Expected behaviour

The manage your account page loads on id.atlassian.com

h5. Actual result

A *Transaction not found* error is shown on the screen on a tooltip next to the verification code field, the console shows the following message:
{code}(!) Failed to load resource: the server responded with a status of 403 (Forbidden)
Page reloaded at 12:09:26 PM{code}
{code}https://auth.atlassian.com/guardian/api/verify-otp{code}

h4. Notes

- Pressing enter seems to be the trigger of the issue (Possibly performed by security applications for auto login), since it is not reproducible without this action, pressing enter is not needed since the validation occurs automatically once the 6 digits are on the field.
- Once it fails, even refreshing the page won't make it work.
- An invalid code does not trigger the issue.
- Limited to Safari, impacts the latest supported version.
fields.summary: 2FA gives a "Transaction not found" when validating the verification code on Safari
